items.message: Sea spray overtopping is forecast along the coast as a result of high tides.  First forecast high water is 07:15 on 03/03/22 with a level of 6.47 mAOD and a Force 4 South East wind. Second forecast high water is 19:45 on 03/03/22 with a level of 6.22 mAOD and a Force 5 North West wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.  Areas most at risk are the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated Thursday, 03/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.86mAOD at 15:30 on 03/03/22 and 4.78mAOD at 03:45 on 04/03/22.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is above normal for this time of year at 155 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain above normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 04/03/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 11:52 AM on 03/03/2022.
Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale, with the tide being highest at Sandside.
After this tide‚ the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Plan driving routes to coastal roads, which may be flooded.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
We will remove this message by 02:00 PM on 03/03/2022.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have peaked and are steadily falling, with no further rise forecasted. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. 

We continue to monitor the situation.  

Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall slowly on the Upper River Wey, following persistent rainfall over the last few days. River levels could rise again in response to forecast rainfall today 03/03/22 and tomorrow. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads in the Godalming area is still possible today and tomorrow.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this afternoon 03/03/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message: River levels remain high but steady on the Bristol Avon and are falling on the Semington Brook. No property flooding is expected. River levels are high at the Bradford on Avon gauge but are expected to drop towards Thursday afternoon. It is anticipated that this flood alert will be removed later today as the situation is not expected to worsen. Rainfall on Thursday morning may slow the falling water levels. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may have been flooded overnight. This message will be updated by 03:00 PM on 03/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message: River levels remain high at the Tern - Walcot river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. Forecast rainfall today, Thursday, 03/03/22, could result in the river levels remaining high over the next few days. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. We expect river levels to remain high until the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 9am on Friday 04/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen on the River Thame following rainfall over the last few days. Flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue especially in areas close to the river around Dorchester-on Thames, Thame and Stadhampton. Light rainfall showers are forecast today. We expect river levels to continue to rise very slowly before stabilising over the next few days. Levels on the Chalgrove Brook and River Thame upstream of Thame do not currently pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 03/03/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Dernford river gauge following rainfall yesterday, 02/03/22. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Thursday 03/03/2022. We expect flooding to affect River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach. No further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours, but further rainfall is forecast tonight and tomorrow, Friday 04/03/22. We expect river levels to remain high today, Thursday 03/03/2022. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated this afternoon, 03/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are falling slowly at the Mythe Bridge and Upper Pound river gauges as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours that may result in river levels remaining high for several days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 5pm on Thursday, 03/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message: High tides combined with high fluvial river levels will be at their highest between 22:00 and 23:00 this Thursday evening, 03/03/22 and 10:15 and 11:15 Friday morning, 04/03/22. Flooding to roads and farmland is expected at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. Locations affected; low lying land at Lower Rea and Elmore Lane West may be flooded. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. Predicted peaks:- Sandhurst 3.4m to 3.6m 03/03/22 at 22:30 and 3.6m to 3.8m on 04/03/22 at 10:30, Gloucester 3.5m to 3.7m 03/03/22 at 22:15 and 3.6m to 3.8m 04/03/22 at 10:30. Flooding is not expected at other tidal gauge locations. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 14:00 on 04/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message: This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 08:30 AM on Friday 04/03/2022. Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton. The detailed tidal information for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth of 7.46 mAODN at 08:30 AM on 04/03/2022, which is 0.12 m above tide tables, with north-westerly force 3 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables.) There has been light rainfall throughout Thursday morning. The Thursday evening tide at 08:15 PM on 03/03/2022 is not expected to reach the flood alert level. We are expecting a series of high spring tides over the next two mornings and as a result this alert will remain in force until at least Saturday afternoon. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 04/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels.  Flooding is possible on high tides at 22:00 on 03/02/22 and 10:30 on 04/03/22 at Torksey.  Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.   
We expect river levels to peak on the high tide at 23:30 on 05/03/22 at Torksey.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 20:00 on 03/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Sandhurst and Maisemore
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Gloucester river gauge as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels.  Flooding is possible on high tides at Gloucester over the next few days.  We expect flooding to affect Coal Wharf and Riverside, Maisemore, low lying areas on Base Lane, Sandhurst. Sandhurst Lane will be just passable. The A417 at Maisemore may be closed due to flooding. Predicted Peaks:- Sandhurst 3.4m to 3.6m 03/03/22 at 22:30 and 3.6m to 3.8m on 04/03/22 at 10:30, Gloucester 3.5m to 3.7m 03/03/22 at 22:15 and 3.6m to 3.8m 04/03/22 at 10:30.   
We expect river levels to remain high over the next 4 days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 14:00 on 04/03/22, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Thames as a result of high tides. The next high tide is expected at Trowlock Island this afternoon the 3rd of March at 4:00 p.m. and is forecast to reach approximately 5 – 5.15 metres. The river is expected to overtop banks and flood low lying land. The following high tide is expected at 4:15 a.m. tomorrow and is forecast to reach approximately 5 – 5.15 metres. The river is expected to overtop banks and flood low lying land.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. The Thames Barrier is not currently forecast to close for the high tides this afternoon and tomorrow morning. 
This message will be updated this evening, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rhee in Central Bedfordshire, Hertfordshire and Cambridgeshire
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Wimpole river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Thursday 03/03/22.  We expect flooding to affect River Rhee from Guilden Morden to Haslingfield   
No further rainfall is forecast for the next 12 hours, but further rainfall is forecast tonight and tomorrow, Friday 04/03/22.  We expect river levels to remain high throughout today, 03/03/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 03/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels are rising at the Sutton Gault river gauge following persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Thursday 03/03/2022.  We expect flooding to affect the Hundred Foot Washes, also known as the Ouse Washes.   
Further rainfall is forecast tonight and tomorrow.   We expect river levels to remain high throughout Thursday, 03/03/22. 
This information is correct as of 12:10 on Thursday 03 March. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 2 centimetres of water on the road. There are currently no issues on the Welney or Earith causeways.  Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 16:00 this afternoon, 03/03/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Sutton Gault river gauge following persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Thursday 03/03/2022.  We expect flooding to affect The Causeway at Sutton Gault.  
Further rainfall is forecast tonight and tomorrow.  We expect river levels to remain high throughout Thursday, 03/03/2022. 
This information is correct as of 12:10 on Thursday 03 March. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 2 centimetres of water on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
The Environment Agency are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways, who will decide whether to close the road.
This alert applies to SUTTON GAULT CAUSEWAY ONLY.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 16:00 this afternoon, 03/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Pang from East Ilsley to Pangbourne and Sulham Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels rose on the River Pang yesterday as a result of the rainfall over the previous few days. Flooding of roads and farmland occurred as a result, specifically in the Tidmarsh area. Light rainfall showers are forecast today, we expect river levels to remain high as a result. However, they have already begun to lower.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this afternoon, 03/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels on the Chertsey Bourne are currently stable but are out of banks in some locations in Chertsey following persistent rainfall over the last few days. Flooding of some low lying land and roads in Chertsey is expected to continue today 03/03/22 and into tomorrow. 
Further rain is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high and sensitive to further rainfall for the next few days. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this afternoon or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Rain falling overnight on Wednesday and on Thursday morning has kept river levels in the area high. Flooding of low lying land and roads close to the rivers is possible for the rest of today, Thursday 3rd March. No flooding to properties is currently forecast. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and will update this message on Friday morning, 4th March, or earlier if the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the Hoe Stream as a result of persistent rainfall over the last few days, but are now falling slowly. However, there may be continued flooding of low lying land and roads in some locations in and around the Woking area today 03/03/22.
Further light rain is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high and sensitive to further rainfall for the next few days. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 03/03/22, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are still rising very slowly on the Lower River Loddon as a result of persistent rainfall over the last few days. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today 03/03/22, especially in and around Swallowfield, Sindlesham Mill, Winnersh Triangle and Whistley Green.   
Further rain is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high and sensitive to further rainfall for the next few days. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this afternoon 03/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are beginning to stabilise on the River Blackwater and River Loddon in the Swallowfield area, following persistent rainfall over the last few days. River levels could rise again in response to forecast rainfall today 03/03/22 and tomorrow. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads, especially in and around Swallowfield is still possible today and tomorrow.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this afternoon 03/03/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high and are rising slowly on the Addlestone Bourne as a result of persistent rainfall over the last few days. Therefore, flooding of some low lying land and roads in the Addlestone area is expected this morning and through today 03/03/22.
Further rain is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high and sensitive to further rainfall for the next few days. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: River Thames from Hampton and Thames Ditton to Teddington

floodArea.county: Greater London, Kingston upon Thames, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Thames as a result of high tides. The next high tide is expected at Kingston this afternoon the 3rd of March at 4:00 p.m. and is forecast to reach approximately 5.15 metres. The river could overtop banks and flood low lying land, roads and footpaths in some locations. The following high tide is expected at 4:15 a.m. tomorrow and is forecast to reach approximately 5.15 metres. The river could overtop banks and flood low lying land, roads and footpaths in some locations.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. The Thames Barrier is not currently forecast to close for the high tides this afternoon and tomorrow morning. 
This message will be updated this evening, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames

items.message:
A high tide of 4.86m is expected at Richmond at around 3:30pm on Thursday 3rd March. Due to high fluvial flows coming down the River Crane, the Crane Tidal Gates will not be able to close to hold back the incoming tide from the River Thames. As a result, the incoming tide will flow up the River Crane which, when combined with the fluvial flow already in the channel, will push levels very high. Some flooding of gardens and low lying land is expected around Isleworth, although we do not expect any flooding to buildings. Flooding is expected to effect Talbot Road, Percy Road, Napier Road, Haliburton Road, Eve Road and the Northcote Road footbridge. Any flooding is likely to be of short duration covering the period around high tide.   
We will be closely monitoring the situation throughout the day and this message will be updated as the situation changes.
This message will be updated this evening, or earlier if the situation changes.
